The advantages of the Yin function (a beta function) compared with other temperature response functions include that it has only three parameters, and each has a clear biological meaning [ 35]. The function gives a smooth curve as opposed to a series of lines with abrupt changes between them. The function combines the advantages of several equations: an exponential response at low temperatures, a positive linear response at intermediate temperatures, a parabola response at optimum temperatures, and a negative response at high temperatures. The model has been validated with data sets of crop growth (e.g. [ 35, 37]) and various plant-pathogen interactions (e.g. [ 38– 41]). For comparative purposes we also fitted a linear model, with lesion size as the response variable and temperature as the independent variable. The linear model is often convenient and effective when the temperature does not approach or exceed the optimum, which could be the case in one or more of the assays.
